elements.content: A new heteroleptic 1D CuI–ReIV coordination polymer of the formula {CuIReIVCl4(μ-Cl)­(μ-pyz)­[ReIVCl4(μ-bpym)]} n ·nMeNO2 (1; pyz = pyrazine, bpym = 2,2′-bipyrimidine) has been prepared through the CuI-mediated self-assembly of two different ReIV metalloligands, namely, [ReCl5(pyz)]− and [ReCl4(bpym)]. 1 consists of chiral branched chains with an overall rack-type architecture displaying photoemission and magnetic ordering. These results constitute a first step toward making new multifunctional magnetic materials based on mixed 3d–5d molecular systems.
elements.clean_text: A new heteroleptic 1D CuI-ReIV coordination polymer of the formula {CuIReIVCl4(μ-Cl)(μ-pyz)[ReIVCl4(μ-bpym)]} n ⋅nMeNO2 (1; pyz = pyrazine, bpym = 2,2'-bipyrimidine) has been prepared through the CuI-mediated self-assembly of two different ReIV metalloligands, namely, [ReCl5(pyz)]- and [ReCl4(bpym)]. 1 consists of chiral branched chains with an overall rack-type architecture displaying photoemission and magnetic ordering. These results constitute a first step toward making new multifunctional magnetic materials based on mixed 3d-5d molecular systems.

elements.content: A {CuIReIV 2}n branched chain was obtained by combining CuI with the two different [ReIVCl5(pyz)]− and [ReIVCl4(bpym)] metalloligands. This 1D heterobimetallic CuI−ReIV compound exhibits chirality, fluorescence emission, and magnetic ordering, and it can be considered a first step toward making new multifunctional magnetic materials based on mixed nd−5d molecular systems.
elements.clean_text: A {CuIReIV 2}n branched chain was obtained by combining CuI with the two different [ReIVCl5(pyz)]- and [ReIVCl4(bpym)] metalloligands. This 1D heterobimetallic CuI-ReIV compound exhibits chirality, fluorescence emission, and magnetic ordering, and it can be considered a first step toward making new multifunctional magnetic materials based on mixed nd-5d molecular systems.

elements.content: The combination of magnetism and chirality in a molecular compound can permit access to new properties such as magnetochiral dichroism and chiral magnetostructural effects with potential applications in magnetooptical devices. Luminescence is another significant property that is attracting an increasing interest because of its potential applications in optical storage, switching, and sensing. Molecular systems that can exhibit this interesting all-embracing function, that is, the coexistence of chirality, magnetism, and photoluminescence, are particularly appealing.
elements.clean_text: The combination of magnetism and chirality in a molecular compound can permit access to new properties such as magnetochiral dichroism and chiral magnetostructural effects with potential applications in magnetooptical devices. Luminescence is another significant property that is attracting an increasing interest because of its potential applications in optical storage, switching, and sensing. Molecular systems that can exhibit this interesting all-embracing function, that is, the coexistence of chirality, magnetism, and photoluminescence, are particularly appealing.

elements.content: Polynuclear transition-metal complexes have been investigated for their photoluminescence properties because of their application in the area of luminescent materials, especially the compounds with d10 metal centers. These systems can also display magnetic properties when they contain a paramagnetic d n ion. However, quenching of the d10 metal luminiscence by metal-promoted energy and/or electron transfer may occur depending on the nature of the paramagnetic d n metal. Compounds of this type involving 4d and 5d metal ions have been scarcely reported despite exhibiting more diffuse magnetic orbitals, which could enhance the magnetic interactions of 3d analogues. In this context, the ReIV (5d3) ion is very appealing because of the high magnetic anisotropy that the mononuclear ReIV complexes exhibit.
elements.clean_text: Polynuclear transition-metal complexes have been investigated for their photoluminescence properties because of their application in the area of luminescent materials, especially the compounds with d10 metal centers. These systems can also display magnetic properties when they contain a paramagnetic d n  ion. However, quenching of the d10 metal luminiscence by metal-promoted energy and/or electron transfer may occur depending on the nature of the paramagnetic d n  metal. Compounds of this type involving 4d and 5d metal ions have been scarcely reported despite exhibiting more diffuse magnetic orbitals, which could enhance the magnetic interactions of 3d analogues. In this context, the ReIV (5d3) ion is very appealing because of the high magnetic anisotropy that the mononuclear ReIV complexes exhibit.

elements.content: Most of the polynuclear ReIV compounds studied so far are based on mononuclear ReIV complexes with potential bridging ligands, such as oxalate (ox2–), cyanide (CN–), or malonate (mal2–), which have afforded a family of metalloligands that have been used as ligands toward both transition-metal ions and lanthanides, making them excellent building blocks for the synthesis of molecule-based magnetic materials. In comparison, the use of ReIV complexes with aromatic polyimines, such as [ReCl4(bpym)] (bpym = 2,2′-bipyrimidine) and [ReCl5(pyz)]− (pyz = pyrazine), has been much less explored. Nevertheless, the simultaneous use of [ReCl4(bpym)] and [ReCl5(pyz)]− as metalloligands toward fully solvated metal ions seems to be a rather tempting strategy to get heteropolynuclear systems displaying versatile structures and multiple properties.
elements.clean_text: Most of the polynuclear ReIV compounds studied so far are based on mononuclear ReIV complexes with potential bridging ligands, such as oxalate (ox2-), cyanide (CN-), or malonate (mal2-), which have afforded a family of metalloligands that have been used as ligands toward both transition-metal ions and lanthanides, making them excellent building blocks for the synthesis of molecule-based magnetic materials. In comparison, the use of ReIV complexes with aromatic polyimines, such as [ReCl4(bpym)] (bpym = 2,2'-bipyrimidine) and [ReCl5(pyz)]- (pyz = pyrazine), has been much less explored. Nevertheless, the simultaneous use of [ReCl4(bpym)] and [ReCl5(pyz)]- as metalloligands toward fully solvated metal ions seems to be a rather tempting strategy to get heteropolynuclear systems displaying versatile structures and multiple properties.

elements.content: Herein we present our first result based on this new synthetic route, which provided us with a new 1D complex of the formula {CuIReIVCl4(μ-Cl)­(μ-pyz)­[ReIVCl4(μ-bpym)]} n ·nMeNO2 (1; Figure ), where the chirality, magnetic ordering, and photoluminescence properties coexist. 1 is an example of a chiral compound based on the ReIV ion displaying spin canting and photoemission.
elements.clean_text: Herein we present our first result based on this new synthetic route, which provided us with a new 1D complex of the formula {CuIReIVCl4(μ-Cl)(μ-pyz)[ReIVCl4(μ-bpym)]} n ⋅nMeNO2 (1; Figure ), where the chirality, magnetic ordering, and photoluminescence properties coexist. 1 is an example of a chiral compound based on the ReIV ion displaying spin canting and photoemission.

elements.content: View of a fragment of the neutral chain in 1. Hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules have been omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  View of a fragment of the neutral chain in 1. Hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The stoichiometric reaction of NBu4[ReCl5(pyz)] (NBu4 + = tetra-n-butylammonium cation), [ReCl4(bpym)], and Cu­(CF3SO3) (1:1:1 molar ratio) in a CH2Cl2/MeNO2/MeCN mixture of solvents gives brown-orange crystals of 1 after slow evaporation at room temperature (see the , SI). 1 crystallizes in the noncentrosymmetric P212121 space group of the orthorhombic system. The circular dichroism (CD) spectrum confirmed its chirality and also the fact that 1 is an enantiomerically pure CuI–ReIV species (Figure S1 in the ).
elements.clean_text: The stoichiometric reaction of NBu4[ReCl5(pyz)] (NBu4 + = tetra-n-butylammonium cation), [ReCl4(bpym)], and Cu(CF3SO3) (1:1:1 molar ratio) in a CH2Cl2/MeNO2/MeCN mixture of solvents gives brown-orange crystals of 1 after slow evaporation at room temperature (see the , SI). 1 crystallizes in the noncentrosymmetric P212121 space group of the orthorhombic system. The circular dichroism (CD) spectrum confirmed its chirality and also the fact that 1 is an enantiomerically pure CuI-ReIV species (Figure S1 in the ).

elements.content: The structure of 1 consists of neutral bimetallic CuIReIV 2 branched chains with alternating chloro and pyz bridges growing along the crystallographic b axis and bpym bridges at the branches (Figure ). MeNO2 lattice solvent molecules are also present, lying in the voids between the chains. The intrachain Re···Cu distances through pyz and bpym are 6.89(1) and 5.62(1) Å, respectively, whereas that across the single chloro bridge is 4.11(1) Å. The intrachain Re···Re distance is ca. 6.47 Å, and the Re–Cl–Cu angle is 120(1)°.
elements.clean_text: The structure of 1 consists of neutral bimetallic CuIReIV 2 branched chains with alternating chloro and pyz bridges growing along the crystallographic b axis and bpym bridges at the branches (Figure ). MeNO2 lattice solvent molecules are also present, lying in the voids between the chains. The intrachain Re⋅⋅⋅Cu distances through pyz and bpym are 6.89(1) and 5.62(1) Å, respectively, whereas that across the single chloro bridge is 4.11(1) Å. The intrachain Re⋅⋅⋅Re distance is ca. 6.47 Å, and the Re-Cl-Cu angle is 120(1)°.

elements.content: The two crystallographically independent Re1 and Re2 atoms from the [ReCl4(bpym)] and [ReCl5(pyz)]− units of 1 are six-coordinate in slightly distorted octahedral surroundings, which are built by four (Re1) and five (Re2) chloro atoms and two bpym (Re1) and one pyz (Re2) nitrogen atoms. No significant differences are observed in the Re–Cl and Re–N bond lengths, with the average values being 2.34(1) and 2.09(1) Å, respectively, which are very similar to those previously reported for polynuclear complexes containing these mononuclear ReIV complexes. Interestingly, the pyz ring is not oriented along the Cl–Re–Cl equatorial interbond directions, but it almost bisects them. The dihedral angle between the mean plane of the pyz ring and the Re2–Cl6–Cl8–Cl9 plane is 141(1)°. Moreover, the pyz ring exhibits a relevant offset from the plane bisecting the bpym ligand, defined by the Re1–Cu1–Re2 set of atoms. The dihedral angle between the pyz ring and that plane is 10(1)° (see Figure S2 in the ). Because of the presence of only one type of enantiomer, the resulting branched chain of 1 is chiral. That orientation is most likely stabilized by intrachain Cl···H–C­(pyz) interactions.
elements.clean_text: The two crystallographically independent Re1 and Re2 atoms from the [ReCl4(bpym)] and [ReCl5(pyz)]- units of 1 are six-coordinate in slightly distorted octahedral surroundings, which are built by four (Re1) and five (Re2) chloro atoms and two bpym (Re1) and one pyz (Re2) nitrogen atoms. No significant differences are observed in the Re-Cl and Re-N bond lengths, with the average values being 2.34(1) and 2.09(1) Å, respectively, which are very similar to those previously reported for polynuclear complexes containing these mononuclear ReIV complexes. Interestingly, the pyz ring is not oriented along the Cl-Re-Cl equatorial interbond directions, but it almost bisects them. The dihedral angle between the mean plane of the pyz ring and the Re2-Cl6-Cl8-Cl9 plane is 141(1)°. Moreover, the pyz ring exhibits a relevant offset from the plane bisecting the bpym ligand, defined by the Re1-Cu1-Re2 set of atoms. The dihedral angle between the pyz ring and that plane is 10(1)° (see Figure S2 in the ). Because of the presence of only one type of enantiomer, the resulting branched chain of 1 is chiral. That orientation is most likely stabilized by intrachain Cl⋅⋅⋅H-C(pyz) interactions.

elements.content: The four-coordinate, distorted tetrahedral environment at the Cu1 atom of 1 is built by two nitrogen atoms (N2 and N4) from the bpym ligand of the [ReCl4(bpym)] terminal unit and one nitrogen atom (N6a) from one bis­(monodentate) pyz ligand and one chloro atom (Cl9) from the two adjacent [ReCl5(pyz)]− bridging units. The Cu–N bond lengths involving the bpym ligand (average value of ca. 2.07(4) Å for Cu1–N2 and Cu1–N4) are somewhat longer than that of the pyz ligand [1.92(5) Å for Cu1–N6a], with all of them being very close to those found for the CuI ion in a similar tetrahedral geometry. The neutral chiral branched chains growing along the b axis of 1 have an overall rack-type architecture, where the [ReIVCl4(bpym)] units, playing the role of platforms, are linked to the CuI ions of the linear [CuIReIVCl5(pyz)] n motif acting as a rung. In addition, two neighboring chains of identical chirality related by a screw axis are further interconnected through edge-on Cl···π interactions, involving the Cl4 atom and the pyrimidine rings of the bpym ligand from adjacent [ReCl4(bpym)] peripheral units [Cl4b···C3 = 3.221(9) Å], in such a way that they constitute a molecular zipper (Figure S3 in the ). The shortest interchain Re···Re and Re···Cu distances are 6.371(8) and 6.294(8) Å, respectively. In the crystal of 1, additional Cl···Cl contacts between different zippers [Cl2···Cl3 = 3.60(1) Å] occur. A 3D supramolecular framework results through weak edge-on Cl···π interactions involving Cl5 and Cl6 atoms and the pyz rings (Figure S4 in the ).
elements.clean_text: The four-coordinate, distorted tetrahedral environment at the Cu1 atom of 1 is built by two nitrogen atoms (N2 and N4) from the bpym ligand of the [ReCl4(bpym)] terminal unit and one nitrogen atom (N6a) from one bis(monodentate) pyz ligand and one chloro atom (Cl9) from the two adjacent [ReCl5(pyz)]- bridging units. The Cu-N bond lengths involving the bpym ligand (average value of ca. 2.07(4) Å for Cu1-N2 and Cu1-N4) are somewhat longer than that of the pyz ligand [1.92(5) Å for Cu1-N6a], with all of them being very close to those found for the CuI ion in a similar tetrahedral geometry. The neutral chiral branched chains growing along the b axis of 1 have an overall rack-type architecture, where the [ReIVCl4(bpym)] units, playing the role of platforms, are linked to the CuI ions of the linear [CuIReIVCl5(pyz)] n  motif acting as a rung. In addition, two neighboring chains of identical chirality related by a screw axis are further interconnected through edge-on Cl⋅⋅⋅π interactions, involving the Cl4 atom and the pyrimidine rings of the bpym ligand from adjacent [ReCl4(bpym)] peripheral units [Cl4b⋅⋅⋅C3 = 3.221(9) Å], in such a way that they constitute a molecular zipper (Figure S3 in the ). The shortest interchain Re⋅⋅⋅Re and Re⋅⋅⋅Cu distances are 6.371(8) and 6.294(8) Å, respectively. In the crystal of 1, additional Cl⋅⋅⋅Cl contacts between different zippers [Cl2⋅⋅⋅Cl3 = 3.60(1) Å] occur. A 3D supramolecular framework results through weak edge-on Cl⋅⋅⋅π interactions involving Cl5 and Cl6 atoms and the pyz rings (Figure S4 in the ).

elements.content: The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1 under the form of a χM T versus T plot are shown in Figure . At room temperature, the χM T value is ca. 2.44 cm3 mol–1 K, which is somewhat smaller that that expected for two magnetically isolated ReIV (5d3, t2g 3, S Re = 3/2) ions, with the CuI (3d10, t2g 6eg 4, S Cu = 0) ion being diamagnetic. Upon cooling, χM T values decrease first slowly and then faster, reaching a minimum value of 1.15 cm3 mol–1 K at 10 K. Then χM T values exhibit an abrupt increase and a further decrease at lower temperatures. This increase of χM T is more pronounced at lower dc magnetic fields (see the inset in Figure ) because saturation effects are thus minimized.
elements.clean_text: The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1 under the form of a χM T versus T plot are shown in Figure . At room temperature, the χM T value is ca. 2.44 cm3 mol-1 K, which is somewhat smaller that that expected for two magnetically isolated ReIV (5d3, t2g 3, S Re = 3/2) ions, with the CuI (3d10, t2g 6eg 4, S Cu = 0) ion being diamagnetic. Upon cooling, χM T values decrease first slowly and then faster, reaching a minimum value of 1.15 cm3 mol-1 K at 10 K. Then χM T values exhibit an abrupt increase and a further decrease at lower temperatures. This increase of χM T is more pronounced at lower dc magnetic fields (see the inset in Figure ) because saturation effects are thus minimized.

elements.content: χM T versus T plot for 1. The inset shows the temperature and field dependences of the χM T product in the temperature range 2–30 K and under the indicated dc fields. The solid lines are only guides for the eye.
elements.clean_text: 2  χM T versus T plot for 1. The inset shows the temperature and field dependences of the χM T product in the temperature range 2-30 K and under the indicated dc fields. The solid lines are only guides for the eye.

elements.content: The magnetic behavior of 1 in the high-temperature range is governed by the zero-field splitting of the ReIV ions and/or the antiferromagnetic interactions between these 5d metal ions (Figure S5 in the ). The abrupt increase of the χM T values in the low-temperature domain can be attributed to spin canting because of the weak intra- and interchain interactions that are mainly transmitted through Cl···Cl contacts. Indeed, a characteristic hysteresis loop of weak ferromagnets is observed at 2.0 K for 1 with values of the remnant magnetization (M r) and coercive field (H c) of 0.065 μB and 1200 G, respectively (Figure S6 in the ). The great anisotropy of the ReIV ion and the occurrence of a noncentrosymmetric space group in 1 account for this phenomenon, as previously observed in related ReIV systems. Evaluation of the canting angle (α) can be performed through the equation sin α = M w/M s, where M w is the magnetization induced by a very weak magnetic field, as observed in the FCM curve using H = 100 G (see Figure S7 in the ), and M s is the saturation magnetization. Although no saturation is reached in the M versus μ0 H plot (M being the molar magnetization and H the applied dc field; Figure S6 in the ), a value of 1.1° for α can roughly be estimated by assuming extrapolated values of M s and M w ≈ 0.07 μB at 2.0 K. This α value for 1 is within the range of those usually reported for ReIV-based compounds behaving as weak ferromagnets.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic behavior of 1 in the high-temperature range is governed by the zero-field splitting of the ReIV ions and/or the antiferromagnetic interactions between these 5d metal ions (Figure S5 in the ). The abrupt increase of the χM T values in the low-temperature domain can be attributed to spin canting because of the weak intra- and interchain interactions that are mainly transmitted through Cl⋅⋅⋅Cl contacts. Indeed, a characteristic hysteresis loop of weak ferromagnets is observed at 2.0 K for 1 with values of the remnant magnetization (M r) and coercive field (H c) of 0.065 μB and 1200 G, respectively (Figure S6 in the ). The great anisotropy of the ReIV ion and the occurrence of a noncentrosymmetric space group in 1 account for this phenomenon, as previously observed in related ReIV systems. Evaluation of the canting angle (α) can be performed through the equation sin α = M w/M s, where M w is the magnetization induced by a very weak magnetic field, as observed in the FCM curve using H = 100 G (see Figure S7 in the ), and M s is the saturation magnetization. Although no saturation is reached in the M versus μ0 H plot (M being the molar magnetization and H the applied dc field; Figure S6 in the ), a value of 1.1° for α can roughly be estimated by assuming extrapolated values of M s and M w ~ 0.07 μB at 2.0 K. This α value for 1 is within the range of those usually reported for ReIV-based compounds behaving as weak ferromagnets.

elements.content: Next, the alternating-current (ac) magnetic properties of 1 in zero dc field were also investigated in the temperature range 2.0–18.0 K and with a variable frequency of the 3.5 G ac field (ν = 500–1000 Hz). A sharp peak was observed at ca. 10 K in both the χM′ and χM″ versus T plots (Figure S8 in the ), and no prominent frequency dependence was observed, confirming the occurrence of long-range magnetic ordering in 1.
elements.clean_text: Next, the alternating-current (ac) magnetic properties of 1 in zero dc field were also investigated in the temperature range 2.0-18.0 K and with a variable frequency of the 3.5 G ac field (ν = 500-1000 Hz). A sharp peak was observed at ca. 10 K in both the χM' and χM" versus T plots (Figure S8 in the ), and no prominent frequency dependence was observed, confirming the occurrence of long-range magnetic ordering in 1.

elements.content: Excitation (dashed line) and emission (solid line) spectra for 1 collected in CH3CN at room temperature. The concentration of 1 was adjusted to A = 0.20 at λ = 295 nm.
elements.clean_text: 3  Excitation (dashed line) and emission (solid line) spectra for 1 collected in CH3CN at room temperature. The concentration of 1 was adjusted to A = 0.20 at λ = 295 nm.

elements.content: Finally, we have investigated the excitation and emission spectra of an acetonitrile solution of 1 by using λexc = 295 nm and setting the absorbance at 0.20. 1 shows a strong emission band at λem = 355 nm (Figure ) of higher intensity and wavelength than the emission displayed by the [CuICl­(bpym)] model compound (see Figure S10 in the ). The observed luminescence in 1 was unexpected because of the presence of the ReIV ion, a paramagnetic center, which commonly would act as a quencher of emission by the electron-transfer process. The luminescence in 1 is then assigned to a π* → π transition of the bpym bridging molecule, similar to other aromatic nitrogen heterocycles found to exhibit identical intense emission bands at λem = 340 nm in acetonitrile.
elements.clean_text: Finally, we have investigated the excitation and emission spectra of an acetonitrile solution of 1 by using λexc = 295 nm and setting the absorbance at 0.20. 1 shows a strong emission band at λem = 355 nm (Figure ) of higher intensity and wavelength than the emission displayed by the [CuICl(bpym)] model compound (see Figure S10 in the ). The observed luminescence in 1 was unexpected because of the presence of the ReIV ion, a paramagnetic center, which commonly would act as a quencher of emission by the electron-transfer process. The luminescence in 1 is then assigned to a π* → π transition of the bpym bridging molecule, similar to other aromatic nitrogen heterocycles found to exhibit identical intense emission bands at λem = 340 nm in acetonitrile.

elements.content: In summary, 1 is a chiral chain that exhibits magnetic ordering below 10 K through spin canting. In addition, 1 displays fluorescence emission at λem = 355 nm. It is well-known that CuI systems generally show photoluminescence properties both in the solid state and in solution; a typical CuI emission appears in the visible range in the solid state and in solution as well, but no luminescence from the CuI centers was detected for 1. The persistence and mandate of the fluorescence of the bpym ligand in 1 even though coordinated to the paramagnetic quencher ReIV ion and the absence of an emission band from the CuI chromophore are rather complicated, and their investigation is still underway. In any case, the coexistence of chirality, magnetic ordering, and luminescence in 1 reveals that our ReIV-based synthetic route, by using two different ReIV precursors simultaneously, constitutes an alternative and straightforward procedure to prepare new multifunctional nd–5d systems in the near future.
elements.clean_text: In summary, 1 is a chiral chain that exhibits magnetic ordering below 10 K through spin canting. In addition, 1 displays fluorescence emission at λem = 355 nm. It is well-known that CuI systems generally show photoluminescence properties both in the solid state and in solution; a typical CuI emission appears in the visible range in the solid state and in solution as well, but no luminescence from the CuI centers was detected for 1. The persistence and mandate of the fluorescence of the bpym ligand in 1 even though coordinated to the paramagnetic quencher ReIV ion and the absence of an emission band from the CuI chromophore are rather complicated, and their investigation is still underway. In any case, the coexistence of chirality, magnetic ordering, and luminescence in 1 reveals that our ReIV-based synthetic route, by using two different ReIV precursors simultaneously, constitutes an alternative and straightforward procedure to prepare new multifunctional nd-5d systems in the near future.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format, preparation of 1, Table S1, and Figures S1–S10. The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acs.inorgchem.5b00502.

metadata.title:
A Chiral, Photoluminescent, and Spin-Canted {CuIReIV
2}
n
 Branched
Chain
